As a Christian, I could argue that the majority religion of the western world for the past 1500 years has been very effective at promoting education and science. However, to be true to the question, one must stick to the phrase "logical perspective". This would preclude a straight-forward answer to the question.  Logic is, rigorously, the practice of connecting premises to conclusions via rational thought. And the problem here is that a "religion", properly defined, amounts to a series of premises. Christianity, for example, involves a "creation statement" ("How did the world come into being?"), a "tale of the fall" ("How did we get to be the way we are?"), a "history" (of mankind, and our various attempts over the centuries to fix ourselves), and a "redemption story"... ("How God has addressed our situation.")  The problem with invoking Logic to resolve the religious question is that, in order to do so, one must already have decided how the world they live in "really is". This amounts to making the judgement to be passed into one of the premises to be assumed up front. Atheists, for example, are generally Materialists and Reductionists. Science is the proper method to understand the world, and there are no "spirits" or purposeful and intentional powers or processes at work around us. Some atheists (e.g. Richard Dawkins) are more overtly of this camp than others, but that tends to be the way for atheistic and humanistic philosophy. Well, there is the impasse as it were. If a Christian starts with a belief in the reality of his mind, of free will, of moral perception, etc... and concludes from these that there is a "spiritual universe" as well as a physical one, then the belief that "moral impulses" reflect a real truth, and that ultimate reality must therefore be a "Person" (like God), then much of the doctrines of the Christian faith will flow from this, or fall naturally into it.  But if one starts with the idea that material and non-personal objects and forces are the "Real Universe", and that deterministic processes are the final arbiter of all events, including our behavior, then of course (from that perspective) religion in general (and Christianity and similar religions in particular) will make no sense at all.  Therefore, the question being posed is (rigorously) unanswerable. We all often want to "see how things really are", and then "choose how we react to the Universe, in keeping with the data". Alas, God in His wisdom has not seen fit to allow us that (simplistic) choice. He responds by saying "You choose... and then by your choice be made known!" That is the actual answer... Pick a world-view, then act upon it. It's not a "scientific", mathematical or logical choice. I am an engineer, so it is very difficult to say this, but I'm afraid it is more like "Artistic Expression". You have to "reach within yourself" and decide what you really believe to be "The Truth" about other people and the world around you. That is, ultimately, what you will find yourself doing, one way or the other.

Religion usually amounts to a claim that reality is more than the sum of its parts and that there is an invisible, supreme force above and beyond the known universe that affects everything and guides our destinies. Such a thing may happen to be true, but apart from anecdotal evidence, there is no reason to believe that it is true. It is a continuing delusion from which mankind will probably never be free. That being the case, if one is going to pay attention to religion at all, he should ask what it says about reality and what its implications are for the problem of suffering. Spinoza’s philosophy, as I understand it, more or less identifies the Supreme Being with the universe itself. That’s all very well, but it seems to make a Supreme Being superfluous. Hinduism, though having thousands, even millions, of gods, posits an underlying reality in Brahma that unifies everything, an ocean of being into which individual personalities eventually dissolve, when they pierce the veil of illusion and achieve enlightenment. Hinduism also attributes human and animal suffering, as I understand it, to karma, an accounting for bad deeds in a previous life. The goal of human life is to pursue enlightenment, breaking free from the cycle of karma, even though this may take thousands of lifetimes. C.S. Lewis said that if he were not a Christian, he might have embraced Hinduism. Buddhism says there may be gods, but they are not relevant to the purpose of Buddhism, per se, which is to come to know one’s true self and to break free of the chain of karma and enter nirvana in one lifetime, instead of many, as taught by the Hinduism from which Buddhism is derived. Buddhism attributes suffering to illusion and attachments. Stoicism, an ancient philosophy that is enjoying new popularity in our day, also stresses freedom from attachments and inner composure in meeting the vagaries and mischances of life. Marcus Aurelius wrote: Either there is a fatal necessity and invincible order, or a kind Providence, or a confusion without a purpose and without a director. If then there is an invincible necessity, why dost thou resist? But if there is a Providence which allows itself to be propitiated, make thyself worthy of the help of the divinity. But if there is a confusion without governor, be content that in such a tempest thou hast in thyself a certain ruling intelligence. And even if the tempest carry thee away, let it carry away the poor flesh, the poor breath, everything else; for the intelligence at least it will not carry away. The three Abrahamic monotheisms—Judaism, Christianity, and Islam—claim that there is one god (though Christianity confuses the issue with its doctrine of the trinity), that He is all-powerful, all-wise, and all-holy, that humanity fails to live up to his pure moral standard, and that we may be made acceptable to God by right belief, right practice, or, in the case of Christianity, being “born anew” by faith in Jesus. The last two of these faiths claim to supersede the first, while Islam claims to supersede the first two. The inescapable problem of monotheistic faiths is that an all-powerful and all-wise god must have created humanity knowing the suffering that would follow and, thus, becoming ultimately responsible for it. Ironically, so far from his creatures needing to repent to him, it is he who owes them an apology for having created them in the first place. An interesting variation on all this is the philosophy expressed in a 40-page essay, The Lazy Man’s Guide to Enlightenment, by Thaddeus Golas, written about 40 years ago. Golas says that the universe is made up of one kind of thing, that everything is alive, and that enlightenment comes from loving acceptance of reality as it is. One may be in heavenly bliss right now merely by accepting everything in life; conversely, if one is in a state of terrible suffering, it is something he has done to himself through his thoughts, even though he may not realize it. The Lazy Man's Guide to Enlightenment - Wikipedia The text has often been available free online, and reading it is an interesting thought experiment. Again, the two basic questions facing any religion are What is reality?Why is there suffering?Reality is either nothing but energy and matter or, no matter how it seems, there is “something more,” invisible, powerful, irresistible, its actions unknowable. Suffering happens either because of the mysterious and unfathomable purposes of a Supreme Being or because sh*t happens. Religions are valuable as records of humanity’s attempts to come to grips with these two issues. Almost all of these attempts were unsuccessful and should be abandoned except as historical curiosities.

Which is the most logical and scientific religion? Bottom line all ancient and contemporary religions are based on very old ideas rooted in an era of scientific ignorance. What does it mean to say that something is logical?Logic is a rigorous and and formal way of thinking. Its goal is to provide the rules to determine if a statement is true given the truth value of other statements. We can call something logical when it makes use of logic and does not violate any rules of logic. That makes that mathematics is logical and most of technology and science too. Wat does it mean for something to to be scientific?Science is a method. It starts with a falsifiable hypothesis. Puts it to the test and does so repeatedly. If evidence cumulates and all points in the same direction, eventually a hypothesis or set of hypotheses becomes accepted as a theory. Science uses logic, experiments and observations as tools for building a body of knowledge about reality. How about religion?None of the world religions has the main goal to build a body of knowledge based on falsifiable claims. Religions have a focus on traditions, rituals, community building, meditation, supernatural experiences and in some cases even blind faith in fact about the world. How about eastern religions?I address the specific claim that some people make that Buddhism or Hinduism are scientific. The arguments starts from the weaker claim that they are less dogmatic, more like a philosophy, and do not require believe in supernatural beings, making them compatible with science.  However claiming that Buddhism is scientific because it doesn't  contradict science is faulty logic. Music and art don't contradict science but we don't consider Bach or van Gogh as scientific.Core concepts like Brahman Atman karma and philosophical ideas about the nature of time do not fit with the contemporary scientific ideas. And these religions do not aim to scrutinize and test their ideas to adjust and build on them. Since none of the regions qualifies for being called logical and scientific we cannot say which one is the “most” logical and scientific.

OK, I’ll first rule out any religion requiring faith in the existence of a deity, because that is not logical. I don’t know how many that leaves us with, but the only ones I am personally aware of are Confucianism, Buddhism, Taoism, Unitarian Universalism, and Scientology. Scientology we can exclude because it requires faith in the existence of a whole bunch of ridiculous stuff. It’s a pay-as-you-go program, as much a religion as Esperanto is a language. Confucianism is a rational, prescriptive, almost Aristotelian religion. Taoism is more mystical as an approach to apprehending the meaning of life and the universe. Buddhism is actually a vast spectrum of religious practices, encompassing individual mystical experience at one end but also fairly rigid liturgy at the other. Universalism is an umbrella religion encompassing many belief systems—some religious and some not—and wrapping them in a churchlike community. But in the big picture, none of them can be seen as logical, because religion is not intended to answer questions in a logical way, it is intended to help people find their place in the world and in society through belief. After all, every logical argument begins with assumptions or premises that are outside logic, and that is where religion operates. If you just want to be logical, then try agnosticism (since any attempt either to prove or disprove the existence of a deity is illogical), and pile science and mathematics on top of it.

Different philosophies use different grids. A culture is a group of people with rather similar grids. Through a window we view chaos, and relate it to the points on our grid, and thereby understand it. The order is in the grid. That is the Aneristic Principle. Western philosophy is traditionally concerned with contrasting one grid with another grid, and amending grids in hopes of finding a perfect one that will account for all reality and will, hence, (say unenlightened westerners) be true. This is illusory; it is what we Erisians call the Aneristic Illusion. Some grids can be more useful than others, some more beautiful than others, some more pleasant than others, etc., but none can be more True than any other. This may be the most important question ever posted on Quora. Roman Catholicism is demonstrably the most realistic and the most rational religion. The demonstration might be very involved, and probably would make a whole host of other questions that could, and perhaps, ought to be asked. But initially, we could say a few things. Many religions assert that the world our senses perceive is an illusion, and our goal is to reach “real” reality. This is an understandable human reaction to suffering in the world. Catholicism, by contrast, asserts the world is real. Not only is suffering real, it also has value in light of the Cross. And to alleviate the suffering of another is an act of charity. Catholicism presents reasoned and time-tested answers to life’s difficulties, without pretending they are illusory. It may be that the religions that call this life an illusion do so because of their inability to provide real solutions to real problems.
